01.text: This begins the account of the resurrection of Jesus from the dead.

01.ref: Now late on the Sabbath, as it began to dawn toward the first day of the week
01.text: "After the Sabbath ended, as the sun came up on Sunday morning"
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Matthew starts to tell a new part of the story.
"the other woman named Mary." This is Mary the mother of James and Joseph. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:mat:27:54|27:56]])
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows. Your language may have a way of doing this.

01.ref: there was a great earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descended ... and rolled away the stone
01.text: Possible meanings are 1) the earthquake happened because the angel came down and rolled away the stone (ULB) or 2) all these events happened at the same time (UDB).
a sudden and violent shaking of the ground

03.text: This is a simile that emphasizes how bright in appearance the angel was. AT: "was bright like lightning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

03.ref: his clothing as white as snow
03.text: This is a simile that emphasizes how bright and white the angel's clothes were. AT: "his clothing was very white like snow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is a simile that means the soldiers fell down and did not move. AT: "and fell to the ground and lay there like dead men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

05.text: "Mary Magdalene and the other woman named Mary"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom the people and the soldiers crucified" or "whom they crucified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

05.ref: He has risen from the dead ones
05.text: The phrase "from the dead ones" refers to the place where the spirits of those who have died go. AT: "but he has come back to life"

05.ref: tell his disciples, 'He has risen from the dead ones. See, he is going ahead of you to Galilee. There you will see him.'
05.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "tell his disciples that he has risen from the dead and that Jesus has gone ahead of you to Galilee where you will see him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

05.ref: going ahead of you ... you will see him
05.text: Here "you" is plural. It refers to the women and the disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "you" is plural and refers to the women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

08.text: "Mary Magdalene and the other woman named Mary"
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows. Your language may have a way of doing this.
This is an ordinary greeting, much like "Hello" in English.
"got down on their knees and held onto his feet"

11.text: This begins the account of the reaction of the Jewish religious leaders when they heard of Jesus' resurrection.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Matthew starts to tell a new part of the story.
Here this refers to Mary Magdalene and the other Mary.
This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of doing this.
"decided on a plan among themselves." The priests and elders decided to give the money to the soldiers.

11.ref: Say to others, 'Jesus' disciples came ... while we were sleeping.'
11.text: If your language does not allow quotations within quotations you may translate this as a single quote. AT: "Tell others that Jesus' disciples came ... while you were sleeping"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_quotations]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

14.ref: If this report reaches the governor
14.text: "If the governor hears that you were asleep when Jesus' disciples took his body"

14.ref: we will persuade him and take any worries away from you
14.text: "do not worry. We will talk to him so that he does not punish you."

14.ref: did as they had been instructed
14.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "did what the priests had told them to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

14.ref: This report spread widely among the Jews and continues even today
14.text: "Many Jews heard this report and continue to tell others about it even today"
This refers to the time Matthew wrote the book.

16.text: This begins the account of Jesus meeting with his disciples after his resurrection.

16.ref: they worshiped him, but some doubted
16.text: Possible meanings are 1) they all worshiped Jesus even though some of them doubted, or 2) some of them worshiped Jesus, but others did not worship him because they doubted.
It can be stated explicitly what the disciples doubted. AT: "some doubted that he was really Jesus and that he had become alive again" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

18.ref: All authority has been given to me
18.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "My Father has given me all authority" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "heaven" and "earth" are used together to mean everyone and everything in heaven and earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Here "nations" refers to the people. AT: "of all the people in every nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to authority. AT: "by the authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are important titles that describe the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

20.ref: even to the end of the world
20.text: "until the end of this age" (UDB) or "until the end of the world"
